etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in John Davies (1625–1693), translator. From re- + fire

definitions: To set light to again; to reignite or rekindle.
To bake or dry (tea leaves) for a second or subsequent time, typically in order to improve the quality and taste of the finished tea.
To fire (pottery) for second or subsequent time, typically in order to set a glaze which has been applied to repair or further decorate a piece.
To fire (a gun) again, especially after reloading.
To dismiss or discharge (a person) from employment for a second or subsequent time.
